Pre-Game Insights: Yankees manager Aaron Boone felt a tap on his shoulder, glancing to find Anthony Rizzo by his side. Unable to play due to a couple of fractured fingers on his right hand, the first baseman was simply an observer as his team battled the Royals on this evening, bouncing between roles as cheerleader and fan.
Gleyber Torres said that the crowd was especially loud in Game 1, and the home team is hoping for that same environment to make a difference in Game 2.
The Royals' pitching staff issued an uncharacteristic eight walks in Game 1, and manager Mike Quatraro said he didn’t believe it impacted his pitching staff, which just didn’t execute pitches.
Royals manager Mike Quatraro will continue to rely on lefties Sam Long and Kris Bubic in high-leverage innings, as well.
The Yankees' 'pen should be fully stocked thanks to Sunday’s off-day.
The Yanks made it through Game 1 without incident.
The offense finally showed some life in Game 1 with good swings off Gerrit Cole, including MJ Melendez’s homer for the first Royals’ dinger of the postseason.
Verdugo reached base three times in Game 1, including a deciding RBI single in the seventh inning.
Austin Wells became the seventh Yankee all-time, and first since Judge in 2017, to reach base three times in his first career postseason game.
Judge went 0-for-4 with a walk and is hitless in his last nine at-bats dating to the regular season.
The Yankees have announced that Clarke Schmidt will start Game 3.
Luis Gil will be available in relief and would return to the rotation for a potential ALCS.
The Yankees were 24-7 against the AL Central this season, a group that includes the three remaining AL playoff teams (Royals, Tigers, Guardians).
Miscellaneous Highlights: Royals-Yankees AL Division Series Game 2 will be played on Monday at 7:38 p.m. ET.
The game can be seen on TBS, truTV and Max.
All games are available in the U.S. on MLB.TV (authentication to a participating Pay TV provider is required).
The Royals' rotation stands with Lorenzen back.
The Yankees present a challenge because of their lineup, but that doesn’t mean the Royals can’t be aggressive in the zone.
The Yanks won three of four at Kansas City from June 10-13, denied a sweep by Maikel Garcia’s two-run walk-off double off Holmes.
The Yanks took two of three in the Bronx Sept. 9-11, including Jazz Chisholm Jr.’s walk-off 11th-inning single in the series finale.
Kansas City and New York played seven games this season, with the Yankees winning five.
The Yanks won five of seven games against the Royals this season.
The Royals' stars -- Witt, Pasquantino and Perez were just 1-for-14 in Game 1.
Kansas City's pitching needs to get back on track after issuing eight walks on Saturday and allowing six runs.
Royals manager Mike Quatraro said he didn’t believe it impacted his pitching staff, which just didn’t execute pitches.

The Royals' lineup leans heavily right-handed, but second baseman Michael Massey has taken such good at-bats and played such good defense this postseason that Quatraro still kept him in the lineup, batting him sixth instead of leadoff.
The hope is Garcia gets on base, creates some chaos there, and maybe that gets Bobby Witt Jr. a fastball or two to feast on.
The Royals will face their first lefty this October, so their lineup leans heavily right-handed.
The Yankees' lineup will still contain a left-handed presence in Game 2.
The batting order that Boone went with for Game 1 threatened, but was unable to break through for a big inning, despite putting up six runs.
Alex Verdugo gets bumped up a spot to No. 8 after coming through with a go-ahead knock in the opener, while Jon Berti makes his first career start at first base.
Gleyber Torres, the Yanks' second baseman, said that the crowd was especially loud in Game 1, and the home team is hoping for that same environment to make a difference in Game 2.
